summary:
In light of the employer-employee relationship between the appellants and the complainant; the
existing dispute between them relating to the employment; the absence of any references to specific
words used, contextual details, or accompanying gestures—whether preceding or succeeding the
alleged words—the failure to mention the use of any "filthy language" in the complaint; and the fact
that this allegation is only found in the chargesheet: there are serious concerns regarding the claim
of insulting modesty of the complainant by the appellants. The conclusion that emerges from the above discussion is that it will be essential for this Court
to carefully assess the evidence presented, in order to determine whether there is sufficient material
to establish the intention and knowledge on the part of the appellants, to insult the modesty of the
complainant or, to put it pithily, whether any act was (1995) 6 SCC 194 intended to shock the sense
of decency of the complainant being a woman. xxxxxxxxxxxx A reading of the definition of ‘criminal intimidation’ would indicate
that there must be an act of threatening to another person, of causing an injury to the
person, reputation, or property of the person threatened, or to the person in whom
the threatened person is interested and the threat must be with the intent to cause
alarm to the person threatened or it must be to do any act which he is not legally
bound to do or omit to do an act which he is legally entitled to do.”
35. At the outset, we record that none of the two complaints lodged by the complainant - the first on
26th October, 2013 and the next on 23rd December, 2013 - does with any degree of clarity and
certainty suggest the presence of the second accused at the time of the alleged occurrence in the
office premises of the Company.

Confidentiality.excerpt: The complainant further asserted that the laptop contained proprietary intellectual property, specifically codes and other work, that she had personally created

Termination.excerpt: She claimed that she was coerced into resigning under duress, with the threat of immediate termination if she did not comply

Liability.excerpt: Hence, there is no basis for the prosecution to set forth the concept of liability of the employer or for the overt acts of its employees in this matter

Dispute Resolution.excerpt: Moreover, it is evident from the case presented by both parties that a dispute existed between them with regard to the employment in question

Governing Law.excerpt: 24 January, 2025 Author: Dipankar Datta Bench: Prashant Kumar Mishra, Dipankar Datta 2025 INSC 105                                                                REPORTABLE                                        IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA                                       CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION                                     CRIMINAL APPEAL NO

Intellectual Property.excerpt: The complainant further asserted that the laptop contained proprietary intellectual property, specifically codes and other work, that she had personally created

entities:
Organizations: October,
2013. The NCR states that the employees of the Company, Company, that is, the appellants, and not by the Company, Sections 323, 504,
506, and 511 of the IPC.
B. Secondly, the Company, Indian Penal Code, 186012. The FIR states that the Company, Report11 was lodged by the complainant
accusing the Company, Human Resources Manager at the Company | People: Badrinarayana Jaganathan, Kanwar Pal, Fiona Shrikhande, Criminal Petition, Labour Court, Madhushree Datta, Indian Kanoon, Case Crime | Dates: April 2014
